_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The covered process at Buffalo Rock is an Ammonia Refrigeration process that is Program Level 3 with an inventory of approximately 11,000 lbs of Anhydrous Ammonia. The audit consisted of two days of RMP procedures and system review, facility walkthrough, and interviews to evaluate compliance with EPA's 40 CFR Part 68. The "U.S. Environmental Protection Agency Checklist for Risk Management Program Inspections or Audits at Program 3 Stationary Sources" was utilized to perform the audit. All Subparts of the regulation are covered in the checklist with comments (document attached).

SUMMARY OF RESULTS:
The result of the audit showed basic compliance with 40 CFR Part 68s. The following summary is from the above referenced checklist which is attached to this document:
Subpart B - Hazard Assessment - 68.20 - 68.42 - The following items within subpart B section are being updated as required by the standard (every 5 years or when process changes occur).
	68.22 Offsite consequence analysis
	68.25 Worst-case release scenario analysis
	68.28 Alternative release scenario analysis
	68.30 Defining offsite impacts - population
	68.33 Defining offsite impacts - environment

Subpart D - Program 3 Prevention Program - 68.65 - Process Safety Information
	68.65(b) Process Safety Information - SDS locations and accessibility are adequate.
	68.65(c) Technology of the Process:
	Process technology data exists:
¿	Safe upper and lower limits for temperatures, pressures and flows
¿	Evaluation of consequences of deviations
¿	All data regarding 68.65(c) organized for easy access and review.
	68.65(d) Process Equipment Design:
		Process design data exists:
¿	Electrical Classification and Safety systems (interlocks, detection, suppression) are implemented or being developed and documented as needed.
¿	Updating equipment designed with obsolete codes or standards as per 68.65(d)(3).
	68.67     Process Hazard Analysis (PHA):
¿	Existing PHA is updated and revalidated as any chan

ges occur
	68.69     Operating Procedures:
		Operating procedures exist, Procedures reviewed, updated and organized for easy access and readability for those employees who work in or maintain the process.
		Must include each operating phase:
¿	Steps for each Operating Phase
¿	Initial Startup
¿	Normal Operation
¿	Temporary Operation
¿	Emergency Shutdown
¿	Emergency Operations
¿	Normal Shutdown
¿	Startup following a Shutdown
¿	Operating Limits
¿	Consequences of Deviation
¿	Steps required to correct or avoid deviation
¿	Safety and health considerations
¿	Properties and hazards of chemicals in the process
¿	Precautions to prevent exposure
¿	Control measures if exposure occurs
¿	Quality control of raw materials
¿	Special or unique hazards
¿	Safety systems and their functions

		Operating procedures being reviewed annually certified by Buffalo Rock to reflect any changes in equipment or chemical technology.
		Safe work practices being reviewed and documented, readily accessible with documented training.


	68.71     Training:
		Training records are being updated regarding the covered system. Most training is done via 			OJT by Southeastern Refrigeration. HazCom and Emergency Response training records 			exist.
	68.73     Mechanical Integrity:
		Preventive Maintenance program is in a changeover and a new program being implemented- 
		Inspections and tests are being performed on equipment and recorded and shown to be consistent with manufacturer's specifications.
		Records showing verification of suitability of spare parts and maintenance materials are 			readily accessible via the Maintenance Department.
	68.75     Management of Change:
		MOC procedures exist, records are available to show compliance with standard, this 		includes updating of PSI and Operating Procedures as well as training.
	68.77     Pre-Startup Review:
		Pre-Startup Review procedures exist, are available to show compliance with 		standard, including confirmation of th

e following:
¿	Construction and equipment are in accordance with design specifications
¿	Adequate safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place
¿	MOC of 68.75 implemented
¿	Training of each employee
	68.79     Compliance Audits:
		Subpart D compliance audits are required every 3 years by a knowledgeable person of the 			process - 	Procedures and records show that this section is due by the end of 2018.
		System problems and subsequent corrective actions are implemented on a timely basis.
	68.61     Incident Investigation:
		Incident investigation is adequate, and records show compliance.
	68.83     Employee Participation:
		Employee participation is adequate
	68.85     Hot Work Permit:
		Hot work procedures and permit form are adequate.
		Permit form should be revised to include post hot work observation for 30 minutes.
	68.87     Contractors:
		Procedures exist for contractor safety 
		All parts of 68.87 must are fully implemented and are being documented.
	68.90     Applicability - 68.95 Emergency Response Program:
		Buffalo Rock in practice relies on Birmingham or Homewood FD to respond to emergencies regarding accidental releases, along with the ERP designees on the ERT to respond to both containment and cleanup. ERP is revised and updated accordingly.
		Current ERP updated and revised according to clearly identify and define the hazards 			and response procedures for all aspects of operations.
		ERP has been partially updated in the last 5 years, due to recent expansion of the current facilities. Currently finalizing ERP as new personnel have come onboard.
	68.15     Management:
		Buffalo Rock has a Director of Maintenance and a Director of Environmental Health and Safety assigned as qualified personnel to manage the RMP system with responsibility for development and implementation of the RMP program elements.
